paper_abstract: Most Adaptive and Intelligent Web-based Educational Systems (AIWBES) use tasks in order to collect evidence for inferring knowledge states and adapt the learning process appropriately. To this end, it is important to determine the difficulty of tasks posed to the student. In most situations, difficulty values are directly provided by one or more persons. In this paper we explore the relationship between task difficulty estimations made by two different types of individuals, teachers and students, and compare these values with those estimated from experimental data. We have performed three different experiments with three different real student samples. All these experiments have been done using the SIETTE web-based assessment system. We conclude that heuristic estimation is not always the best solution and claim that automatic estimation should improve the performance of AIWBES. (C) 2013 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
paper_title: An empirical study on the quantitative notion of task difficulty
